Fairstone CEO stresses importance of regional investment after major growth 12:55, 30 Aug 2016 12:55, 30 Aug 2016 By Robert Gibson Initial support from Northstar Ventures allowed Boldon-based financial planning firm Fairstone to more than double turnover Shares Get business news by email Chief executive of Fairstone Group Lee Hartley 
The head of a North East finance company that has grown the biggest of its kind in the country has spoken of the need for continued investment into the North East economy. 
Boldon-based Fairstone, which is now the country’s largest chartered financial planning firm, received early support from the EU ’s Jeremie fund, which has supported a number of North East start-ups but whose future is in doubt following the Brexit vote. 
CEO Lee Hartley said the investment was a vital “strategic building block” that helped the company on the growth journey that now sees it manage more than £6bn in client assets and employ more than 250 advisors around the country. 
Between 2013 and 2015, Fairstone received a total of £1.5m of investment from the Finance for Business North East Accelerator Fund, managed by Northstar Ventures. 
It recently received a £25m investment from private equity firm Synova Capital to aid its growth plans. Alasdair Greig of Northstar Ventures 
Mr Hartley, who founded the business, said: “The impact regional investment can have should not be underestimated – particularly in light of the current discussions surrounding Brexit and the Northern Powerhouse. 
“With the investment and support we received from Northstar Ventures, Fairstone was able to increase its annual revenues from £15m at the inception of the relationship to its current run-rate of £36m. 
“In addition, Northstar’s involvement and guidance was pivotal in enabling us to transition away from a shareholder base comprising mainly of high-net-worth individuals through to professional Private Equity shareholders – a changeover which was crystallised in the new £25m equity investment in April this year.” 
Fairstone operates nationally, but has kept its headquarters in Boldon. 
Aside from support from Northstar Ventures, it benefits from a strong relationship with Northumbria University, with which it runs a dedicated graduate recruitment programme. 
Northstar, which is currently investing from three North East-focussed funds, was recently named the sixth most active venture capital investor within UK start-ups. 
Research conducted by PitchBook - an international database covering venture capital, private equity and mergers and acquisitions - found that since 2014, 607 venture capital firms have made at least one investment into UK-based start-ups. 
In the same period, Northstar made 34 investments, all into North East companies. 
Northstar director Alasdair Greig said: “In the last few years we’ve seen the local business community thrive, with start-ups across the region including Middlesbrough , Sunderland and Newcastle attracting talent and finance from other areas of the UK and beyond. 
“Without access to regional investment, these companies may have been forced to relocate in order to compete for funding.” 
He added that Northstar had also seen a growing willingness from other VCs and private investors to invest outside of London, and to support Northern entrepreneurs. 
“The investments we’ve made from the Finance for Business North East Proof of Concept and Accelerator funds alone have leveraged £168m additional investment into North East companies since 2010,” he said. 
“Companies like Fairstone are a huge asset to the North East economy and are evidence of how successful regional investment strategies have been in recent years.”
